QRCodeDecoder

Browser-ready QR Code decoder in Javascript

Using Lazar Laszlo's port of ZXing Java library, QCodeDecoder brings to the web a great interface for dealing with QRCode decoding, being usable both on desktops and mobile phones. See the compatibility table

Install

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Quae omnis doloribus nobis repudiandae in accusamus, at earum quaerat consectetur, soluta molestias! Obcaecati natus nesciunt facere, laborum non exercitationem saepe numquam.

Installing the lib is super damn easy. Just downloaded it and include in your page or fetch it using Bower, the package manager for the frontend.

$ bower install -s qcode-decoder

Don't forget to contribute to the project! Go fork it on Github

QCodeDecoder keeps everything simpe, trying to do well for only a few things.

There are mainly three things to do with the library: decode a qr-code directly from camera (i.e, the phone's front/back camera, your webcam or whatever), from a video or from an image.

The simplest case is decoding from an image. It only requires passing to the decodeFromImage method the image's source or an image element that has a src attribute set.

  var image = document.getElementById("image");
  QCodeDecoder()
    .decodeFromImage(image, function (error, result) {
      console.log(result);
    });

Just like decoding from camera, a video can also contain a QRCode in it. Although not the common case, it is also exposed as it is a part of the Camera code.

Decoding from camera requires, firstly, access to the user's camera. For getting this, QCodeDecoder will ask the user about it (this process is required so that browsers are able to keep it secure) and, if conceived, start searching for a valid QRCode to decode.

Note that if you need to have a valid QRCode and a camera to try this one. If you don't have, check the video sample.

  var video = document.getElementById('video');

  QCodeDecoder()
    .decodeFromCamera(video, function (error, result) {
      if (error) throw error;

      console.log(result);
    });

see on github
